stream_context.summary: Kaze Emanuar worked on Course 14, named 'Handmade Heights'. The primary focus was programming and fine-tuning the complex physics for a paper airplane object to create a dynamic flight path. He also implemented a Toad NPC, animated a rubber band launcher, and showcased recent performance optimizations for N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately chose to create a complex, physics-based system for the paper airplane's movement instead of a simpler, scripted spline path because he prefers mechanics to have an emergent, physical basis.
development_findings.quote: Of course, I can just put it on a spline, but then I just have to add a spline and doing these computations, I prefer that. That's why there's some kind of physical basis for it. Even if I'm fudging the numbers and the physical basis a lot and approximating things.

development_findings.summary: The paper airplane's flight path was developed through a long process of trial and error, tweaking variables for velocity, pitch, and friction to balance the system between being too chaotic (endless backflips) and too stable (a boring flight).

Kaze identified and fixed a bug in the Fast64 toolchain where the first frame of an animation was being cut due to a 'smart animation range' feature, which was preventing the rubber band animation from starting correctly.

Significant performance improvements have been made for running the game on N64 hardware, including an anti-aliasing toggle that allows some areas to reach nearly 50 FPS. The game is now described as 'RSP bottlenecked'.
The project utilizes F3DX3, a newer and faster microcode that enables performance optimizations like occlusion planes and triangle strips, which influences level design possibilities.

While developing dialogue for a Toad NPC, Kaze briefly experimented with using ChatGPT for ideas but immediately rejected the output as poor quality, preferring to write his own 'soulless' and 'mechanical' text.
development_findings.quote: Visitor detected, dispensing star. Take it. Okay, that's shit.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered a bug, which he believes is present in the original Mario 64, where pressing the A button on the first frame after being shot from a cannon causes an error.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong belief that lack of time is a poor excuse for not working on personal projects, expressing a 'no excuses' work ethic.
context_findings.quote: I've always been a hater for people that are like, oh, I can't work on my R64 because I have school. Bitch, school is like six hours a day. You still are awake for 10 hours a day beyond that. You have all the time you want and you're just being a pussy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the modern 3D platformer genre has a low bar for success, and that a game can become a fan favorite simply by being competent and avoiding major flaws.
context_findings.quote: I think the bar for 3D platformers is so incredibly low that making a 3D platformer is easy at this point... if you just make a hack or make a game that doesn't suck, I think it's going to be popular. That's my theory on the matter.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is cynical about the Analogue 3D console, speculating that the company is not sending him a review unit because they know the product is flawed and want to avoid a negative review from him.
context_findings.quote: My logic is, if they're not sending me a review copy or an early copy to review it, surely there's a reason for that. And surely that means it's garbage, right?

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a conflicted relationship with streaming; he enjoys it but gets intensely frustrated by chat's questions, revealing a tension between his public-facing development process and his personal focus.
context_findings.quote: I often get very, very annoyed at chat when they just ask really stupid questions. But it is what it is, man. What can I do, really? I do kind of really like streaming. It's just that sometimes I just can't deal with it, I think.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans for his next project to be a commercial 3D platformer built in Unreal Engine 5, which he considers 'practical' despite believing most modern engines are 'bloated pieces of shit'.
Kaze is dismissive of the current capabilities of AI for complex game development tasks like programming physics, stating it couldn't handle the work he is doing.
context_findings.quote: AI is horrendous at programming at the moment. It's not going to be able to figure any of this out.

biobak.summary: Biobak was present in the stream chat. Kaze's greeting suggests a familiar and casual working relationship.
biobak.quote: Hello, Biobak. Welcome to programming this and getting annoyed by chat. What else is new?

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned that Zeina created the animations for the Toad NPC, and he identified a need for an additional animation for when the Toad gives a star, indicating a collaborative workflow where he implements her work and provides feedback.
zeina.quote: I like the animations to say no, but I think there should be an animation for when he gives you the star.

key_stories.title: The Paper Airplane Physics Problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream programming the physics for a paper airplane. His goal was a dynamic, swooping flight path, which proved to be a difficult balancing act between chaos and stability. Through iterative tweaking, he achieved the desired behavior, demonstrating his preference for emergent mechanics over scripted events.
key_stories.challenge: To program a paper airplane object that flies with a dynamic, swooping motion rather than a simple, straight path, and lands precisely on a target.
key_stories.process: Kaze iteratively adjusted physics parameters like velocity, angular pitch, and friction. He fought to find a balance between a system that was too stable (boring) and too chaotic (uncontrollable backflips). He rejected using a simple spline path in favor of this more complex, physics-based approach.
key_stories.outcome: After extensive live debugging and tweaking numerous physics variables, Kaze successfully created a flight path with the desired 'swoop' behavior that felt dynamic and landed correctly on the pyramid.
key_stories.key_quote: We just kind of need to fudge the equations in a way that we get the result we want.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions Zeina's animations for the Toad NPC and greets Biobak in chat, but the specifics of their collaborative process (e.g., how feedback is given, how tasks are assigned) are not discussed.
questions: Can you walk us through the typical workflow between you and Zeina for an animated character? How does an idea go from concept to implementation?
What is the creative feedback loop like with Biobak? Does he provide finished art, or is there more back-and-forth during the development of a level's visual theme?
How are creative decisions resolved when there are differing opinions between team members?

open_questions.topic: Game Design Philosophy: Physics vs. Scripting
open_questions.context: Kaze spent a great deal of time 'fudging' physics numbers for the paper plane, explicitly stating he prefers a physics-based system over a scripted one like a spline.
questions: You spent a lot of time 'fudging' the physics for the paper plane. Where do you draw the line between a believable physics simulation and just making something that 'feels' right for gameplay?
Why is it important for you that game mechanics have this 'physical basis,' even if it's heavily approximated and requires more work than a scripted alternative?

open_questions.context: The level being worked on is called 'Handmade Heights' and features a mix of distinct biomes like desert, styrofoam mountains, and a castle.
questions: What is the core creative idea or narrative that ties the distinct biomes of 'Handmade Heights' together?
How does the 'handmade' or 'craft' theme influence the specific gameplay mechanics you're building for it, beyond just the visuals?

open_questions.context: Kaze expresses intense frustration with chat questions but also says he enjoys streaming. This creates a visible tension during the broadcast.
questions: You have a very direct relationship with your chat. How does that immediate, unfiltered feedback—both the good and the bad—actually influence your development process?
How do you balance the need for deep focus with the interactive, and sometimes distracting, nature of streaming your work live?
